poem:
**Eden Park Reverie**  

Beneath the agapanthus sky,  
the game unfolds in hushed sunlight—  
white-dotted players dance  
across a canvas of green whispers.  
Helen sits, arms wide,  
holding the languid rhythm of the day,  
a forgotten art of waiting—  
where time, like a cricket ball,  
spins gently in the stillness.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Long, unhurried days with a cooler: the cricket fans sticking with New Zealand’s forgotten format From the spot where Helen Julius spread her arms across the peeling, sun-flecked green paint of the pavilion’s bench seats, Eden Park’s Outer Oval in Auckland was almost picturesque. There were the white-clad cricketers – Auckland batting, Canterbury in the field – and a bank of agapanthus just beginning to break out in flower beyond the sight-screen on the ground’s". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
